blog.name: pokegodsandmissingno
blog.title: P̵o̵K̸é̴G̸o̸D̷s̸ and Frightful Things to Come?
blog.description: There is a growing desire and expectation of humans here on Earth in making full contact with PoKéMoN who are still unknown. Back in 1995, when I saw my first UPM (Unindexed Pocket Monster), I found out very quickly that other people thought you were totally crazy if you said you saw such things. The world has changed quite a bit since then when I was a child. In fact, in late 1997, a poll taken in Kanto shows that for the first time ever, more than fifty percent of residents now believe in PokéGODS's. Since then, there have been polls that put the figure at over eighty percent or more.

Loudred’s bellowing can completely decimate a wood-frame house. It uses its voice to punish its foes. This Pokemon’s round ears serve as loudspeakers.

- Pokemon Omega Ruby

blog.name: inikavulpixelreviews
blog.title: Let's Talk About Pokemon!
blog.description:
Reviewing my personal opinion on every single Pokemon! Yes, all 809 of them!
(Mostly) Daily Uploads, 3 PM EST.

summary: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - Vullaby and Mandibuzz
title: Let’s Talk About Pokemon - Vullaby and Mandibuzz
body:
629: Vullaby

Here’s a pair of Pokemon that took me a while to warm up to. While a Vulture/Buzzard is an animal that would’ve been on my make-this-into-a-Pokemon wishlist had it not been done by now, these aren’t the most ideal executions on what I was hoping for but they’re certainly not disappointing Pokemon.

Vullaby’s got plenty to like. It’s a stubby little baby bird adorably tiny wings, a fat lil body and a rough hairdo looking much like the unrefined first coat of baby birds. For the longest time, I thought it was wearing its eggshell as a diaper, but no! Actually, it turns out it’s a skull. Which makes me appreciate it so much more. It’s a perfectly clever way to invoke the scavenger nature of vultures too, getting their children to wear the skulls of the carcases they eat. That’s just badass.

Though admittedly I’m still mostly indifferent to Vullaby itself here. Something about its face just doesn’t rub me personally the right way. I think it’s the face to beak ratio. Even baby vultures have some big honkin beats in comparison to their face, so why not this friend too? Feh.

Personal Score: 7/10

It’s a shame I got that one big nitpick. Vullaby alone could’ve beaten out Braviary if it weren’t for the face turn-off.

630: Mandibuzz

Mandibuzz, the evolved form, is one hell of a bird though. It gets all the cool vulture parts you could’ve asked for. The rad beak, the neck-ruff, the mean face, and that awkward-looking bare-skin head and neck. The skull-pants is replaced with a more toothy skirt detail with a bone though the thing’s “ponytail.” It’s really giving off a caveman aesthetic, which is a more than fun way of getting the vulture’s carcase-cleaning nature across by making them wear their prey’s bones like accessories. The one shame about Mandibuzz’s overall presentation is perhaps the name. While yes, obviously meaning “buzzard + mandible”, it sounds a little too much like a name more fitting for a Bug type. In fact, when the english names got leaked, I was confused and thought it was Durant that was called Mandibuzz for at least a few minutes. But they’re still the typing that was meant for a Vulture, being a Dark/Flying type. Nice.

One more strange thing that isn’t a deal breaker is the fact that this species is all-female for… some reason. Just like how Braviary is all-male. Usually when that’s done to a pair of Pokemon, it’s meant to signify that the two species are the “male” and “female” of the same creature. So Mandibuzz is just. A species of bone-collecting moms. It’s just a weird choice.

Personal Score: 9/10

Super rad vulture friend.

Overall:

Hey. I like birds. Vultures are some cool ass birds. And These two, while maybe not exactly being what I was hoping for, does not disappoint.

[Archive]
